Absolutely. Individual responsibility is essential in combating propaganda on social media, and fact-checking information is a necessary step to avoid spreading propaganda. It is essential to understand that not everything shared on social media is true or accurate, and sharing false or misleading information can harm others' perceptions and contribute to the spread of propaganda.

Individuals must take the time to verify the source and accuracy of the information before sharing it. This may involve checking multiple sources, examining the facts, and consulting trusted experts in the subject matter to ensure that the information being shared is credible.

Moreover, individuals must understand how propaganda works and how to identify disinformation tactics, such as misinformation, logical fallacies, or manipulation of facts. By being knowledgeable on these tactics, individuals can protect themselves and others from propaganda and contribute to a more informed and ethical public discourse.
